369069: Plasm Capture.author: Aelvr
369069: Plasm Capture.text_parsed:
@hypa_dude Pfffffft I'm sorry, what? Do you even Simic? There is no way that this thing is overpowered. Maybe a little overpowered if it was , but even then, it wouldn't have near the power level of cards like Supreme Verdict or Detention Sphere.

This thing can be really hard to mana fix for unless you are playing a lot of multi-colored lands; and if you a playing capture, you are trying to ramp, which means the ETB-tapped lands are setting your ramping plans a turn behind. It also means that the earliest you can cast this is turn 4, maybe 5. And then you didn't spend the mana summoning creatures or ramping, which means you can be behind yet another turn, and in the end your ramping gamble doesn't pay off when your opponent plays 4 1-drop unleash/haste creatures--or worse, nothing--and breaks your unguarded face. And if it's late enough in the game that you can summon a relevant fatty AND still have mana for Plasm Capture, it's late enough in the game that you need a hydra for the bonus mana to be relevant, so at that point, I'd rather have Cancel.

Oh? I should be running Prophet of Kruphix if I want to play creatures on my turn AND Plasm Capture on theirs? Sure, but the card still needs 2 blue mana and 2 green mana, and EVEN THEN it's Prophet of Kru-fix making this card even look good, which sounds more like interesting and less like OP to me.

369070: Viashino Firstblade.author: HawkeaterMoth
369070: Viashino Firstblade.text_parsed:
As a long time Viashino fan I concur that this is the best Viashino printed since Urza Block. I used a casual tribal deck full of Viashinos in 1999, but the only decent ones were the Viashino Cutthroat, Viashino Sandstalker, Viashino Sandscout and sometimes the Viashino Heretic. The rest were solidly mediocre and every one printed since they returned in Invasion has been completely underwhelming...underpowered and too expensive to cast.

But it is puzzling that he doesn't have first strike.

369071: Profit // Loss.author: Mistralis
369071: Profit // Loss.text_parsed:
I think the way this is supposed to be good is not for fuse.
There is one main advantage I can see- it's two cards in one. You basically draw two instants. That's two choices.
It's basically a Glorious Charge and a strictly better Cower in Fear in one card, with the option of casting both together if wanted.
But yes, for both effects, definitely go Zealous Persecution.

But since this is split (though horrendously overcosted), if for some reason, you wanted to get extra damage in but make sure your opponents' creatures don't die (dying effects or something), then here you are.

369071: Profit // Loss.author: majinara
369071: Profit // Loss.text_parsed:
Modern version of night / day.

Advantages of Profit / Loss:
- profit costs less mana than day
- profit can't be redirected
- night hits all creatures a player controls
- fuse

Advantages of Night / Day:
- day can also be cast on other people, making it better in multiplayer games (especially team games)
- night costs one mana instead of three

369071: Profit // Loss.author: Mode
369071: Profit // Loss.text_parsed:
While it doesn't necessarily deserve a rating that low (right now ~2.1), you can see the community's frustration about it.

While most other split cards have a huge impact when fused, this one is just like:
"Haha, did you just seriously pay to get something another spell could have given you for ?"
If if you decide to only use one side instead, it will still be like:
"Haha, did you just seriously pay 2 or 3 mana to get half the effect of something another spell could have given you for the same amount or even less mana?"

Yes, it's not a terrible card.
Yes, casting just either half can be easier.
Yes, the left half is stricly better than Warrior's Honor, the right half strictly better than Cover in Fear.

Still, there are a couple of cards that are strictly better than Profit. And that sounds wrong.
And in fact it is, since i actually have to count in the fact that Profit always comes with Loss.
Wait, that still sounds wrong...

Argh. It's just...this card seems so underwhelming and overpriced when fused!
I think there's simply something missing to make fuse more appealing. Maybe a simple addition on Profit like:

"If you cast both halves of this card from your hand, creatures you control get first strike until end of turn."

Granted, it's not the nice, implicit, natural advantage other split cards have (like Beck // Call or Flesh // Blood).
But i'd rather have a blunt, contrieved, explicit advantage than just an underwhelming fuse card.

Combine Trojstani's Summoner with Parallel Lives - gain double the fun... and it does not end here. Combine the previous card combo with Progenitor Mimic and let the token festival start ;D Now you all might say: " what about board whipe?" - my answer to that is our best friend Rootborn Defenses I have never felt more satisfaction compared to when a friend of mine tried to whipe the board and I dropped this baby of a card.. say hello to my army of rhinos, centaurs and knights.. ohh and thank you pal for clearing out the board for me! :D gg wp.

As a bonus info.. this deck would play as G, W, U so ramping up to seven mana should be relatively easy in a casual multiplayer deck.. In standard the combo would work yet getting to the point with it actually start to kick in might be impossible against aggressive decks unless one builds heavy around early defense. Have fun everyone!

369072: Trostani's Summoner.author: Ataraxiom
369072: Trostani's Summoner.text_parsed:
I know that it's tempting to look at this as a 10/10 for 7CMC, but you've also got to remember that this is the Selesnya guild we're talking about. Gaining four creatures off of one card is a huge deal.

Not only does this lady provide you with four bodies to stack an Overrun across, she also allows you to boost cards like Wayfaring Temple very quickly. Any kind of a crowd-based effect is going to adore the summoner, assuming you have some way to gather the mana up to play her.

Believe it or not, I actually prefer Urbis Protector, but that might just be the flavour of the card getting to me.
369072: Trostani's Summoner.text_posted:

369072: Trostani's Summoner.author: Dr.Pingas
369072: Trostani's Summoner.text_parsed:
I love the pure conflict of this card.
First off, the value is fantastic - but is it something you can afford? Its rare to see such value bat higher casting costs, especially while still being fairly underwhelming.
Second, she has a hard time working out well. She's in selesnya, which loves lots of creatures, but that's also her biggest downfall. She tries too much
Three centaur or two rhino would have flowed much better with populate which only hits one token type and prefers a single powerful token like Grove of the Guardian. Your goal isn't as many token types as possible, just one you wanta bunch of.
On top of that, none of them are really supported types - centaurs got some theros love, but ehh? Being an elf herself isn't even that big of an asset.

Its such a neat card, bit its funny how well made it is

369073: Putrefy.author: Umbric
369073: Putrefy.text_parsed:
Doom blade uncommon

Go for the throat uncommon

Ultimate Price is uncommon

Notice all these spells have some type of condition:

"Destroy Nonblack..."

"Destroy nonartifact..."

"Destroy monocolored..."

Murder, common, a pretty vanilla card but also good

Dreadbore, rare, great card in Jund Standard 2 mana removal at the cost of a sorcery

Hero's downfall, rare, 3 cmc at sacrifice for instant speed and a nice upgrade from murder.

Here we have an uncommon 3 cmc that can get Artifacts, creatures, AND can't be regenerated. Now making it a rare from the beginning would have been a great idea but it's too late now. Still always kills me somehow 4/5 and if you get it in a draft it defines what deck you should run.

[autocard]Murder[/autocard], common, a pretty vanilla card but also good

[autocard]Dreadbore[/autocard], rare,  great card in Jund Standard 2 mana removal at the cost of a sorcery 

[autocard]Hero's downfall[/autocard], rare, 3 cmc at sacrifice for instant speed and a nice upgrade from murder.

Here we have an uncommon 3 cmc that can get Artifacts, creatures, AND can't be regenerated. Now making it a rare from the beginning would have been a great idea but it's too late now. Still always kills me somehow 4/5 and if you get it in a draft it defines what deck you should run.

369073: Putrefy.author: FlashCaster
369073: Putrefy.text_parsed:
This is easily one of the top 10 targeted removals in the game, and even better than Vindicate overall in my opinion due to the speed difference. If you are running creatures of your own then killing a PW via creature damage is often possible when packing this. Sure it can't hit lands, but honestly in a tournament I would rather have instant speed that the option to kill a land.

Vindicate is a better card overall thought from my point of view, not because of tournament playability but because it is just so damn cool and iconic.

Putrefy is an easy 4.5/5

369074: Unflinching Courage.author: Ferlord
369074: Unflinching Courage.text_parsed:
I think the one thing that's majorly different between this and cloak is that no matter who controls the creature, you gain the life for cloak.

It kind of creates a pseudo-"Vow of" aura. If you are low on life, you can attach it onto an opponents creature and you'll still gain life. If they attack you, you'd gain the life they just dealt you. Mind you, if they deal lethal, you're up s**t's creek.

I guess the other thing is that this doesn't stack with lifelink. Cloak's ability is a triggered ability, while lifelink's a static ability.

369076: Maze Rusher.author: Mistralis
369076: Maze Rusher.text_parsed:
IMO, usefulness with guilds.


Boros: It's way too high-cost to go into a Boros deck. It's great, but the cost isn't.

Gruul: You can now beat face one turn faster! Pretty good. Curves into Borborygmos Enraged. Cast Maze Behemoth the next turn and prepare to just own.

Izzet: Not the best choice. No creatures that really need haste. Tenement Crasher has haste already, but Cobblebrute may need it. Either way, with six mana, you could do a lot more damage in burn.

Rakdos: It's nice, but I think a lot more people will like Exava, Rakdos Blood Witch. She hits the board faster and has haste herself anyways.

369079: Orzhov Guildgate.author: HoHIndie
369079: Orzhov Guildgate.text_parsed:
@dash85
No, Orzhov Guildgate won't multiply your mana. Similarly to how Plains tap for one white mana and Swamps tap for one black mana, when you tap an Orzhov Guildgate, you choose one color - black or white, in this case - and add one mana of that color to your mana pool. In a superficial sense, it is like having a land that is either a Plains or a Swamp, depending on what you need.
369079: Orzhov Guildgate.text_posted:

369080: Turn // Burn.author: Spheniscine
369080: Turn // Burn.text_parsed:
@Jhyrryl: "Turn and burn" is actually fighter pilot slang. It means to get out of a place quickly. It refers to steering the airplane ("turn"), and then firing the afterburners ("burn").

It's also apparently restaurant biz slang for attempting to maximize customer turnover (serving them quickly so that they would leave quickly).

369080: Turn // Burn.author: Maileesaeya
369080: Turn // Burn.text_parsed:
Oh, how I love this card. It might just be the best fuse card outright, just because the only thing it can't kill is hexproof; the creature has pro-red (IE, Lavinia)? Turn it, then Burn it. Creature has pro-blue (only one right now, Skylasher)? Burn. Opponent swinging at you with small, but annoying flyers? Turn one and block it, Burn the other. Thragtusk? Obzedat? AVACYN? Fuse, bam, dead, for potentially as little as UR if you've got Electromancers en masse.

@Diachronos, Wizards policy seems to basically be to print more versatile cards at slightly higher costs, kind of like how Izzet Charm has can reproduce the effects of different one-cost cards but costs two because it can be any of them. Besides, with this in the same colors as Electromancer, odds are you're already playing it for 2UR.

@skyxtome, this has already been brought up, but no. A fused card is still just one card, it basically translates to "so it's now like an ordinary spell instead of a split card".

369080: Turn // Burn.author: Odee
369080: Turn // Burn.text_parsed:
This is the solution to those aggressive decks that have put Izzet down for most of the Ravnica block. You can potentially wipe two creatures out with a single card - While they're attacking.
Turn the deathtouch, combat tricked, battalion or double-striking creature into a 0-1 weird that promptly gets smashed against your blockers, then burn away the hasting legion loyalist/spark trooper/ash zealot that was coming with it. Or you can just slap someone with two damage upside the head.

It's nice to have another cheap and versatile burning instant that's standard legal as well, my Searing Spears were looking pretty lonely.

I have questions though. Is the fusion counted as a double casting or a single? How does this respond to the Nivmagus Elemental? Can you cast both then nab just one spell and not send the whole card into exile?

369080: Turn // Burn.author: Continue
369080: Turn // Burn.text_parsed:
Used correctly, this can quite easily be a 2-for-1 or even, in some cases, an effective 3-for-1 if you were to, say, Turn someone's Thragtusk while chump blocking (preventing them from getting a 3/3 in the process) and Burn their Huntmaster. It's no Fire and Ice, but it's more than good enough.

@Maileesaeya: Unfortunately, trying to Turn and Burn Lavinia won't work. Going by the rulings, if you cast both halves, the entire thing is treated as being both blue and red, so Lavinia has protection from it. If, however, you were to only cast Turn on her, she would turn into a 0/1 as the spell would be only blue.

@Odee: Once it's fused, it's treated as a single spell.

369080: Turn // Burn.author: patronofthesound
369080: Turn // Burn.text_parsed:
The fact that this is UR targeted, unrestricted creature removal is important. Many fatties are out of the range of most burns and you end up getting 2-for1'd if you can even take them out. The lack of timing restrictions here is crucial for removal in these colors, especially blue. This is worth a red splash in a mono blue deck, which relies on accurately timed counters and bounces to survive. Instant speed makes it pretty glorious. I think it might be a tad slow for standard, but on the other hand maybe I'm just being greedy. At 1U for turn and 1R for burn it would be broken. It's smartly priced, and its versatility and off-color effect (when fused) is well designed.

4.5/5 sick art and design...but loses half a point because it could have had a tad more oomf somewhere. Maybe if burn hit for 3, but only creatures, it'd be perfect. It is five mana and multicolored, after all.

Also, probably better than electrolyze and prophetic bolt in terms of the izzet arsenal.

369080: Turn // Burn.author: Tamerlein
369080: Turn // Burn.text_parsed:
This is one of my favorite Dragon's Maze cards. If you have an Augur of Bolas or something and they swing with two 2/2s, you can burn one and turn the other, and Augur can block the turned creature.

An extremely versatile spell which can take care of a lot of nasty leaving the battlefield effects, such as Thragtusk's beast and Voice of Resurgence's elemental. At its weaker moments it is a five mana "destroy target creature" spell, which isn't actually pretty useful in U/R.

5/5

A question.

I have a polis crusher. In my turn, I stack his monstrosity. In response my opponent casts a turn//burn, using only the turn part. What happens?
369080: Turn // Burn.text_posted:
A question.

I have a polis crusher. In my turn, I stack his monstrosity. In response my opponent casts a turn//burn, using only the turn part. What happens?

369080: Turn // Burn.author: RiptideChimera
369080: Turn // Burn.text_parsed: @ojddw The ability of Polis Crusher reads, "If this creature isn't monstrous, put three +1/+1 counters on it and it becomes monstrous." The 0/1 weird is not monstrous, so it becomes monstrous and gains its counters. That creature will remain monstrous for as long as it exists on the battlefield. The only thing that happens once Turn stops having an effect is that it stops being a weird- it remains monstrous. However, if you're talking something like Hythonia the Cruel, her board wipe will not activate- she never becomes monstrous as Hythonia. Only the weird becomes monstrous, and the weird has no ability that reads, "When it becomes monstrous, destroy all non-Gorgon creatures." As such, Turn is good at denying monstrous abilities like hers, but not so good at denying something like Polis Crusher, who relies on the Monstrous definition to do his work.

369081: Warleader's Helix.author: JaxsonBateman
369081: Warleader's Helix.text_parsed:
How this is only a 3.5 at the time of this post is outrageous. This is one of the best removal spells in limited. There are definite other candidates, and it's hard to go past Putrefy from both an effect, cost and rarity standpoint, but unless you're dealing with a 5+ toughness creature Helix actually has the edge due to lifegain. And anyone who thinks that some bonus lifegain on an otherwise good effect is negligible obviously hasn't had a close race before. And then there are always those times when your opponent is on 4 or less life...

This is a very justifiable first pick in draft - and to get that kind of priority, you have a 4+/5 rating.

As for the comment about Spark Trooper - are you high? 2 damage and lifegain isn't nearly as potent as the ability to directly hit creatures if required. Pretty much the only thing Spark has going in its favor is the ability to contribute to Batallion. Don't get me wrong; it's a solid card, but I'd be much happier with a Helix in its place.

369081: Warleader's Helix.author: sweetgab
369081: Warleader's Helix.text_parsed: After playing with and against this for a while, I found this card to be pretty strong. I was playing green aggro last SGO and went 7-3, two of the matchs I lost were very close -- except the last match against UWR control, which I felt was completely hopeless. Game 2 he went T2 Augur of Bolas revealing Warleader's Helix, T3 Pillar of Flame + Augur of Bolas revealing Supreme Verdict, and T4 Restoration Angel revealing another Warleader's Helix. Normally an aggro deck can try to finish off opponents at 6-10 life via burn and hasty creatures for a few turns after T4-5. Add just one Helix, though, the game is likely lost right there when the last creature is killed.

369082: Armored Wolf-Rider.author: Ataraxiom
369082: Armored Wolf-Rider.text_parsed:
It's amazing how a card this simple can serve so many purposes.

In Limited, it's solid curve-filler that'll demand removal, even without evasion,

In Pauper, he's a valuable member of two very significant tribes,

And for casual games with new players, he's simple enough to teach them the benefits of playing multicoloured decks.

Not to mention he does it all with gorgeous art, courtesy of Matt Stewart. Lovely common.

369083: Skylasher.text_parsed:
People need to stop complaining on every card about power creep. The game's always going to have more and more powerful cards as it grows and as long as the cards aren't at the level of Skullclamp or Jace, the Mind Sculptor and as long as they don't wreck formats, there's nothing to complain about. This is a card that's sideboard material against blue. Sure it's good against blue but in most situations, it's just a bear with flash that can chump block fliers. It doesn't even stretch the P/T curve. It's still just a 2/2 at the end of the day.

Why are people complaining more about Skylasher than Voice of Resurgence which has a massive impact on every game and is clearly not just a 2/2?

369083: Skylasher.author: Phelplan
369083: Skylasher.text_parsed: I am totally a green mage at heart, but I agree that this should cost at the very least. I really don't want to complain about powercreep but I am not a fan of the fact that rares (or worse, mythic rares) can cost the exact same amount as a common and have the power-level be soooooo skewed towards the rare. Sure, give rares and mythics a bit of a boost, but it shouldn't make equivalent-costed commons look like total sh*t when placed alongside - this card does that. And it's the type of thing that makes me angry at Wizards of the Coast when I see it. Because a deck stuffed with all rares is a pay-to-win scenario that makes the game not much fun for those of us who don't want to hand our wallets over to Hasbro.

369083: Skylasher.author: blurrymadness
369083: Skylasher.text_parsed:
4 abilities on a 2/2; I can understand it seems overwhelming but let's not cry power-creep. In most cases it's an Ashcoat Bear with Reach; which is hardly the best thing to throw in a deck. The rest is blue hate; which because blue is so powerful requires multiple abilities just to get protection to work. Even the Flash is there because of blue.

If anything this should be a wake-up call to players that blue is *that good.* When you see 4 abilities on this card; I see a Green White Knight that requires 4 abilities to do the same job as Knight's 2; because it's against blue.

369084: Deputy of Acquittals.author: Drewskithelegend
369084: Deputy of Acquittals.text_parsed:
Anyone else get the impression that the rating is this low simply because it's a common, because I feel like it would be at least a 4 if it were rare. Considering it is a neat little trick that, among other uses, can blink out a creature targeted with a hard removal spell, it deserves higher. It can also be used to reset a card with a good ETB effect without netting you minuses. At the very least it makes for a surprise bear, something that proves quite useful in colors that have a lot of draw power and not much one-for-one removal.
I'm giving it a 4, It's not terribly flashy but it is a good card nonetheless.

369085: Rakdos Drake.author: ThePinkBaron
369085: Rakdos Drake.text_parsed: Keep in mind that Rakdos players would love any sort of evasion, and that the decision to make it 2/3 was very deliberate. 369085: Rakdos Drake.author: DarthParallax
369085: Rakdos Drake.text_parsed: one of my favorite cards in the set because it was a genuine surprise, and cuteish. :) I was mostly actually expecting retarded things like Dragonshift and Progenitor Mimic. When you've been in the game long enough, you start appreciating Spoiler Season as much for Commons and Uncommons as for Mythics and Rares- every set's Mythics and Rares will seem splashy and awesome for a while, but when you notice yourself really caring about how they Design and Develop non-Rares, even if you don't specifically play much Limited, you are making the decision to care about how long will the game be able to continue being itself and fun and cool. Good-Balanced Commons that you can't really make yourself throw away even if you don't shuffle them up outside Limited are what makes the game survive year after year. :)

369085: Rakdos Drake.author: Ferlord
369085: Rakdos Drake.text_parsed:
The obvious problem is you've got a creature who's got higher toughness than power for an ability that is slightly better with a higher power (like Gore-House Chainwalker). It's like how Archweaver has both Reach and Trample. It's like it's a Jack of all Trades, but master of none. Dead Reveler suffered from a similar fate.

However, a Black flyer isn't bad at all, especially in limited, and dealing with a 2/3 in the air is going to be a little bit more difficult than just plopping down a Towering Indrik.

369086: Drown in Filth.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
369086: Drown in Filth.text_parsed:
It's very weird that there are almost no sac-lands in Standard right now. We have Encroaching Wastes and Grove of the Guardian, that's all. There are no Evolving Wilds or Terramorphic Expanses. There are no Haunted Fengrafs or Buried Ruins. There are no Ghost Quarters or Tectonic Edges. There sure as heck aren't any Marsh Flats or Misty Rainforests.

There is no practical way to quickly get lands into your graveyard, except as a side effect of self-milling. Poor little Drown in Filth is still useless. Even the "dredge" decks that use Commune with the Gods, Satyr Wayfinder, and Grisly Salvage ignore DiF. That makes me sad, because I wanted to play with it.

369089: Down // Dirty.author: Fenizrael
369089: Down // Dirty.text_parsed:
Let's stop and compare for a moment.
Treasured Find has 2 cmc but costs AND exiles itself. You're probably not going to be using it on turn 2 either (mill decks excepted).
Down//Dirty costs 3 for return side and DOESN'T exile itself, and has an added discard side to it if you don't really need to return anything. Much more variety in available options. Doesn't matter that you're not running a discard deck, it still gives you card advantage.
Additionally, if you have 2 in hand and 7 mana, you can constantly make your opponent discard while bringing the other one back next turn.
You can also still use it in mono black or mono green.

So... Treasured Find = good speed, limited to deck and one cast only.
Down//Dirty = more variety, card advantage, and potential recursive casting.

Technically this is better. Could stand to be cheaper by but would probably have to be rare then.

369090: Punish the Enemy.author: DarthParallax
369090: Punish the Enemy.text_parsed:
Searing Blaze has shown us that Barbed Lightning and this can suck it. :P

But actually seriously, I think the guy that said 'Overcosted by 1' is pretty close to on it. Searing Blaze was double-colored, triggered on landfall (a semi-tough hoop to jump through with perfect consistency- like Metalcraft and Threshold, if you build for it, it happens, usually, and when it's not on, the card sucks) and when all was said and done, was a little pushed. Searing Blaze is fair to call 'way better than Incinerate' and 'about as good as Lightning Bolt'

I think I'd like to see this at {1}{R}{R} and uncommon...at sorcery speed?

for Limited and Standard, 'Overcosted by 1' is a perfect comment, but I like things that are good enough for Casual and Modern :) (Yes, 'good enough for casual' is a thing. Control decks need to be slower and softer, with good Defender creatures, and Aggro decks need to be faster, like Bolt and Nacatl, without getting near the 'Goyf or Combo range, to be ''Good Enough for Casual"- Good for Limited is not always Good for Casual. IE you want your burn deck to actually work and your blue-black and blue-white control deck to actually work and you want to actually get to see all the colors do their thing.)

A spell that does more than one thing is always valuable in limited.

A spell that deals damage to a creature AND player is fantastic in limited.

369091: Maze Behemoth.author: Mistralis
369091: Maze Behemoth.text_parsed:
IMO, usefulness with each guild.

Selesnya: It's great only sometimes. There are only two kinds of Selesnya creatures: giant ones (Grove of the Guardian), and little ones (Eyes in the Skies). In addition, the centaurs and birds aren't multicolored. Only things like Voice of Resurgance tokens and the like. It's a high cast cost anyways, so by then, you should have those kinds of things. It doesn't really help Selesnya that much though, as token swarm with trample doesn't really work, and if you can get something that big out, you've probably won anyways.

Simic: Like Maze Glider, this card's purpose is fulfilled a lot better by Crowned Ceratok and Sapphire Drake. Not the most useful, but it's okay, I guess. It's a lot easier to use the two others, though, lower casting cost, and it comes with a creature in addition that's good for its pricing. So, not the best.

Golgari: It's pretty good. Your giant scavenged creatures will not get chump-blocked by that damn Ornithopter token again.

Gruul: It's very nice. If you have tons of bloodrush things in your hand but they can clearly chump block, suddenly, it's a viable gamender.

369092: Scion of Vitu-Ghazi.author: Mode
369092: Scion of Vitu-Ghazi.text_parsed:
"I guess they added the "from your hand" part, to avoid combos with cards such as Soul Foundry, that would result in you having any number of such tokens on the battlefield." —majinara

Yeah, they clearly did that since they saw the easy abuse ad infinitum with token copy effects.

It's okay that they didn't want to take the risk.
However, they should still have worded it differently, as the restriction they chose also made it worse in conjunction with other effects that don't intend to abuse it (i.e. any effect that puts the original card onto the battlefield).

It should have been something like:

"When Scion of Vitu-Ghazi enters the battlefield, put a 1/1 white Bird creature token with flying onto the battlefield.
If Scion of Vitu-Ghazi is not a token, populate."


I still consider a restriction unnecessary overall, however. This is a 5 mana card.
Infinity combos across two turns with it (that can be disrupted) shouldn't be that game-breaking.

There are better Splinter Twin targets for instance,
which is another card that works with it and a famous example for combo decks.
369092: Scion of Vitu-Ghazi.text_posted:
"[i]I guess they added the "from your hand" part, to avoid combos with cards such as [autocard]Soul Foundry[/autocard], that would result in you having any number of such tokens on the battlefield.[/i]" —majinara

Yeah, they clearly did that since they saw the easy abuse ad infinitum with token copy effects.

It's okay that they didn't want to take the risk.
However, they should still have worded it differently, as the restriction they chose also made it worse in conjunction with other effects that don't intend to abuse it (i.e. any effect that puts the original card onto the battlefield).

It should have been something like:

"[i]When Scion of Vitu-Ghazi enters the battlefield, put a 1/1 white Bird creature token with flying onto the battlefield.
[u]If Scion of Vitu-Ghazi is not a token[/u], populate.[/i]"


I still consider a restriction unnecessary overall, however. This is a 5 mana card.
Infinity combos across two turns with it (that can be disrupted) shouldn't be that game-breaking.

There are better [autocard]Splinter Twin[/autocard] targets for instance,

369093: Nivix Cyclops.author: SRSFACE
369093: Nivix Cyclops.text_parsed:
This guy did work for me during the prerelease. I won at least two games where this guy and a Hover Barrier or Doorkeeper were in play. I'd target my OTHER wall with Dragonshift and swing for 8 when they weren't expecting me to have any sort of attackers on the field at all. Was pretty sweet and I think I'd like to expand the concept into a constructed deck with tons of defenders to the point I'd be able to overload Dragonshift for the win.

Oh, btw, that +3/+0? That remains even if you turn him into a dragon because his ability activates first and therefore it remains til the end of turn as it activates before Dragonshift successfully turns him into the 4/4 flying dragon.

369093: Nivix Cyclops.author: CogMonocle
369093: Nivix Cyclops.text_parsed:
So just played BRGu, splashing for progenitor mimic, this, and blast of genius, most of the other cards were removal, korozda gorgons... list here: http://tappedout.net/mtg-decks/rtr-brgu-combos/update/

This was my first attempt at 4 colors in draft, it worked out pretty well, almost no mana screw in 6 matches. This guy was an absolute powerhouse. At one point, I had an opponent with 2 bird tokens and murmuring phantasm on the field, 20 life, me at 4 life, and him tapping the cyclops with hands of binding. I play Mind Rot, pit fight making the cyclops kill the murmuring phantasm, then predator's rapport on the cyclops gaining 14 life. A few turns later, I cast horncaller's chant, the following turn, flesh & blood on the cyclops, flesh targeting a 3 power creature, bringing him to 7/7, dealing 7 to my opponent with blood, then swinging for lethal, for 24 damage that turn. I accidentally combo deck.

369094: Warped Physique.author: mdakw576
369094: Warped Physique.text_parsed:
possibly the best 2 mana removal spell for esper decks in standard right now?

For the first 3-4 turns this will kill anything it can target. Lategame, Esper decks can play revelation to keep their hand full and be giving -7 toughness.

The tougher mana cost and keeping the hand full seem to be smaller restrictions than the other current 2 mana kill spells in standard. Devour flesh can be unreliable, ultimate price has a narrow range of targets, victim of night is very tough for multicolor decks and is pretty blank against jund.

The pros is that it can be casted with surprise factor, kills planeswalker, without the chance of being destroyed before activation like Deed would. The cons is that, for the same mana cost, Pernicious Deed could destroy bigger targets than Gaze the turn after it's in play.

Several old greats have been 'retooled' so to speak to fit in standard and modern in Dragon's Maze.



Pernicious Deed is one of the best board sweeps out there, without question. This will never take its place in our hearts or our decks.

But this has a place. And you can bet it's going to be played there.


"Not as strong as Pernicious Deed" is like saying "Not as strong as Superman."

And to be perfectly honest, I'm not going to complain about having to settle for Batman when Superman isn't around.

369095: Gaze of Granite.author: DarthParallax
369095: Gaze of Granite.text_parsed:
This card has something that Pernicious Deed DOESN'T peeps! >:)

*Reprintability*!!! :O It is relatively difficult to imagine Wizards finding good places to put such Weatherlight-flavored cards anymore. I know that Deed is NOT Reserved, but being too closely tied to Old Dominaria Flavor is like being Pseudo-Reserved these days. :P You'd need new art, flavor text, and Mythic Rarity to justify Pernicious in any Precon deck in the future.

This is just Wrath of Gorgons, and can fit anywhere you can fit Swamps and Forests together, because Gorgons are Core Set Flavor. :) I'd be quite surprised if this card never got a Commander-themed Reprint. As in, I believe this card is already slated for near-immediate Reprint!

369095: Gaze of Granite.author: SomeGuy007
369095: Gaze of Granite.text_parsed:
@All the people saying this is better than Punishment: No.

This is certainly a better sweeper than Punishment when you need to clear a board. It hits more permanent types than Punishment, hits a variety of casting costs, and all in all sends more stuff to the graveyard. However, there's a reason that I'm running Punishment in my EDH deck and not Gaze of the Gorgon: Punishment lets you dodge the effect much more than you can dodge this. For example, in an EDH game I was in recently, I had a board of a Lord of Extinction with a Batterskull on it facing down 8 Giant Adephages with an Akroma's Memorial on one side, and a Platinum Angel on a third side. In that situation, Punishment >> Gaze of the Gorgon. I wiped all of the giant bugs out, ended the Memorial that was cramping my Lord's style and was able to swing in to recover all the life I lost to the bugs. With Gaze of Granite, I would have stopped everything all right, but I would have lost my only two cards still on the board in the process, which would have been devastating at the time.

tl;dr: Punishment isn't a worse Gaze of Granite. It's much better at getting X for 1s than Gaze due to the lack of hitting your key cards.

369095: Gaze of Granite.author: Fenizrael
369095: Gaze of Granite.text_parsed:
Comparison time!
Pernicious Deed is fantastic, yes, but it requires a turn to wait in order to properly drop the big one. Your opponent can play around this and stop dropping cards when they see you play it.
Both cards can be cancelled, but Pernicious Deed can also be destroyed with enchantment removal as well. In many circumstances, saccing it early can result in you screwing yourself over. It does have the advantage that you can sac it any time you like (and for more), whereas Gaze of Granite is a bit more surprising and trashes Planeswalkers too.
Keep in mind this can also be brought back and recast and whatnot. Casting it for can often still be quite useful, too.

Still a solid card.

369095: Gaze of Granite.author: blurrymadness
369095: Gaze of Granite.text_parsed:
It's heavier in color weight than the Deed, but most of the time it does the exact same thing; as waiting on Deed may cost you if they have a Krosan Grip or some such.

The Deed can do a couple neat things, like, by waiting to activate it you can cause your opponent to stall on dropping another card next turn; then blow it up anyway when they go to pass turn; making it Time Walk + Planar Cleansing, usually one-sided at that.

Aside from those two small details, this is a modern Deed and cements what G/B does in a nice fair way.

Geez! It hurt's my eye's!

These punctuation mistakes are merely a bad habit than anything else, because they're really not that hard to avoid:
Apostrophes are only used in front of the possessive "s". It's that simple.
Just never add one anywhere else like in plural forms, let alone conjugated verbs - or any verb in general, really.

369097: Give // Take.author: majinara
369097: Give // Take.text_parsed:
Hmm... I don't know what to think about this.

Putting three +1/+1 counters on a guy for three mana is quite efficient. However, being able to do so only at sorcery speed is pretty crappy, since you can't play it as a combat trick that way.

Drawing cards by removing +1/+1 counters is interesting. But again, it would be best at instant speed, so you could do it in response to a removal spell, to still gain value out of a creature that it's about to die. Being sorcery speed cripples this a lot. In addition, you need card draw most in the late game, when an opponent played mass removal, and you have to improve your board presence. But after mass removal has been played, there are no creatures to play this on.

In addition, six mana for both effects is very very expensive.

I really want to like this card, but it just doesn't seem very useful.

It was hard for me to justify playing Take, simply because I was paying 6 mana to draw 3 cards at sorcery speed. I felt at 3 mana a piece Give and Take should've been an instant. 369097: Give // Take.author: BubskeesWGB
369097: Give // Take.text_parsed:
This card won me games. If you're thinking that this is terrible because its 4GU to draw three then you're playing it wrong. Only in the worst cases is it to be played like that.

If you're playing a +1/+1 counter deck, this card is absolutely fabulous. Sometime you just put 3 +1/+1 counters on a creature. Other times you're removing more than 3 +1/+1 counters from other creatures to draw lots of cards, but most importantly, you can put +1/+1 counters on one creature and then remove others from a different creature to draw.

This card is highly variable, and each of its modes is incredibly useful.

I only have 3 questions about this card.

1) If I counter this when my opponent fuses it, does it counter both halves or only one?

2) If I cast this fuse card on 1 Hero creature, would I be triggering that cards Heroic ability twice, because these are technically 2 different cards targeting the same creature? Or would it trigger once because they are the same, physical card?

3) Do +1/+1 counters get removed before or after Heroic resolves?
369097: Give // Take.text_posted:

2) If I cast this fuse card on 1 Hero creature, would I be triggering that cards Heroic ability twice, because these are technically 2 different cards targeting the same creature? Or would it trigger once because they are the same, physical card?

3) Do +1/+1 counters get removed before or after Heroic resolves?

369097: Give // Take.author: Continue
369097: Give // Take.text_parsed: I'm a new soul, I came to this strange world hoping I could learn a bit 'bout how to give and take...
369097: Give // Take.text_posted: I'm a new soul, I came to this strange world hoping I could learn a bit 'bout how to give and take...

369097: Give // Take.author: NickDay
369097: Give // Take.text_parsed:
Hello @AlphaWolfs

1) When you Fuse a spell, both halves count as one whole spell. You would be countering the entire thing.

2) This is "technically" and literally one card. The rules text on the card even says "both halves of this CARD." Again, a Fused spell is still just one spell. If you target one creature with both halves of this card, Heroic only triggers once. If you target two different creatures with each half of this spell then Heroic would trigger once for each of those creatues.

3) Heroic resolves before the spell because Heroic resolves when the creature is targeted by a spell you control. If you target a Heroic creature you control with a spell - even if the spell is countered - Heroic will still trigger.

Hope that helps!

369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.author: Jayquaz
369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.text_parsed:
@anyone who is wondering why some random human is indestructible (flavor wise):

First let me start off by saying that this is probably my favorite legend which is why I did all of this research and bothered to type this all out. The reason he is indestructible is not the awesomeness of his beard/goatee, though I do like that explanation. Actually Tajic is the head Boros guildmage who is also in charge of The Warmind Initiative (http://www.wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/feature/224#boros scroll down to the section about the theaters of war) which is a collaboration between the Boros and the Izzet in charge of producing/developing new weapons, armor, elementals, (Warmind Infantry, Spark Trooper) etc. In addition it would probably be safe to assume that the lead Boros guildmage would be able to make some kind of premanent Boros Charm.

369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.author: hamletface
369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.text_parsed:
Tajic, Blade of the Legion is a great card that has an interesting back story. Tajic is the Boros Legion's most highly ranked Guildmage. He is in charge of the War mind initiative, a collaboration between the Izzet and the Boros. They create electrified walls and checkpoints, steam powered suits for soldiers, powerful armor for Elementals, animated stone soldiers, elemental soldiers (spark troopers), powerful siege machines, weapons, armor, and battlefield traps. Before Tajic was chosen to run the Maze, he was called Advisor Tajic, First Guildmage of the Legion. His indestructibility most likely comes from Aurelia. The Boros smelting wards have magical powers that could allow them to do this. It would not likely be the Izzet because they would probably give their own soldiers this powerful armor.
Now onto gameplay. Tajic is a versatile card for both blocking and attacking. It can attack for 7 as well block your opponents large creatures without dying. You can use Gift of Orzhova to easily give it flying and pump it slightly. Its mana cost is perfect. You can play it on turn four. At turn four you could have played three other creatures by then. This allows you to keep a creature to block, let them kill a creature of yours before turn 4, or allow you to not have played a creature.
I give this card and overall rating of 9.5/10.

369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.author: Ligerman30
369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.text_parsed:
Built in Darksteel Plate. This guy as a general is almost strictly better then Cho-Manno, Revolutionary. Now, I don't think you want to go all in on voltron (which is an option), you want to be able to trigger battalion on a regular basis so in general, your going to need around at least 1/3 of your deck to be creatures making it less voltron and more regular r/w beatdown. Voltron is your backup plan. I mean, they wrath you and you will still have this guy a bunch of equipment and no blockers. Just suit him up with all your gear and swing in for that last bit of general damage. That being said, I shoved a ton of recursion in the deck. So with a general like this, you can really play any style of deck you want, be it, swarm, voltron, beatdown, control even.

The best thing this card has going for it is as a general is allowing for an EDH deck to have a very high threat density. While Lightning Greaves and Swiftfoot Boots don't provide redundant efects like in Geist of Saint Traft they aren't really needed to protect tajic and don't really pressure an opponent and can ultimately be cut for more high impact cards.
369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.text_posted:
Built in [autocard]Darksteel Plate[/autocard].  This guy as a general is almost strictly better then [autocard]Cho-Manno, Revolutionary[/autocard]. Now, I don't think you want to go all in on voltron (which is an option), you want to be able to trigger battalion on a regular basis so in general, your going to need around at least 1/3 of your deck to be creatures making it less voltron and more regular r/w beatdown.  Voltron is your backup plan.  I mean, they wrath you and you will still have this guy a bunch of equipment and no blockers.  Just suit him up with all your gear and swing in for that last bit of general damage.  That being said, I shoved a ton of recursion in the deck.  So with a general like this, you can really play any style of deck you want, be it, swarm, voltron, beatdown, control even.  

The best thing this card has going for it is as a general is allowing for an EDH deck to have a very high threat density.  While [autocard]Lightning Greaves[/autocard] and [autocard]Swiftfoot Boots[/autocard] don't provide redundant efects like in [autocard]Geist of Saint Traft[/autocard] they aren't really needed to protect tajic and don't really pressure an opponent and can ultimately be cut for more high impact cards.

369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.author: DritzD27
369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.text_parsed:
As much as I love this guy I feel like his ability runs headlong against his flavor text. Look at it this way:

1) He says in his flavor that he goes on alone, but with the full might of the Legion.

2) If he does so 'actually' alone (or with one other) then that makes his ability not trigger and he is a wondrous 2/2 entering combat.

So, I suppose by 'alone' he means something other than most people do.

Also, after having seen nearly his entire Standard career, I think it is definitely safe to say that he could have been a 3/3 that got a smaller pump and still probably would only be fringe playable. Such a pity.

369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.author: SAUS3
369098: Tajic, Blade of the Legion.text_parsed:
As a commander, he doesn't do too much on his own, but he works with so many strategies.

Because of how battalion works and because it doesn't scale with more creatures, I think the ideal way to play him is to attack with him and 2 other creatures and that's it. You don't need more because it won't really add that much.

Since he is indestructible, voltron and board wipes are very valuable. It's a little harder to get rid of him, so he loves equipment. board wipes basically become plague wind for much less mana, which is insane - and then you get to attack into empty boards (killing planeswalkers or getting a bunch of stuff off of swords when you hit a player).

Another important factor about how battalion works with him is that the quality of creatures he attacks with doesn't matter. You can have ETB dudes that are no longer useful, tokens, manlands, whatever you happen to have lying around. It could even be some powerful, aggressive creatures like brimaz which will force players into defense. On top of that, having expendable chumps that are there to trigger battalion means it's okay to wrath them away if you need to. Manlands can even completely dodge board wipes and then trigger battalion afterwards.

Then there's the ability to play on defense. Since he is indestructible, he makes a great wall for your planeswalkers. You can even wrath a scary board while leaving your planeswalkers and Tajic in tact. If your opponent over-commits to an attack to kill off the planeswalkers, you can take a huge swing at them with a battalion out of nowhere.

In my Tajic EDH deck, Tajic really doesn't do much on his own, but he supports every strategy in the deck.

5/5 because he's awesome.

369099: Pilfered Plans.author: TheChort
369099: Pilfered Plans.text_parsed:
I'm digging all these value mill cards which you'd almost be playing already;

Pilfered Plans > Divination
Psychic Strike > Cancel

Throw in some Thought Scour, Dimir Charm, Grisly Spectacle... All of which are the perfect lead-in for Consuming Aberration. Add some other solid creatures (Vampire Nighthawk? Desecration Demon?) and clone effects for making additional aberrations (or nighthawks, etc. in a pinch) and you can make a deck that can seamlessly alternate its win condition from death by mill to death by beatdown!

Pilfered Plans in particular seems like a nice card to curve into Consuming Aberration; draw into the aberration/mana you need to cast it, and get a stack going in your opponents graveyard.

369099: Pilfered Plans.author: Ataraxiom
369099: Pilfered Plans.text_parsed:
Between this card and Psychic Strike, UB Mill/Control is finally starting to get some edge over the typical Monoblue builds. Although I can't see it keeping up with the sheer efficiency of a WB Control deck, this certainly gives those decks a reason to look into going Esper.

Having this card, Psychic Strike, and Nephalia Drownyard in a Control build allows you to mill out your opponent without really deviating from the Control strategy you had in the first place. I mean... you were probably going to be using some Cancel or Divination type effects anyways, right?

I love how splashing a second colour can upgrade an already-solid card like this. Certainly not core-set material, but a wonderful way to give a plane like Ravnica some personalized flavour.

369099: Pilfered Plans.author: Opeth2010
369099: Pilfered Plans.text_parsed: I'm feeling like this is a pretty good card. It's a little surprising that it isn't seeing any play in Standard. Divination sees play in Standard, so why not this? I'm thinking this belongs, not necessarily in a Dimir Control deck necessarily, but actually in Esper Control. The reason being that we used to be able to Azorius Charm an attacking creature, and then mill it away if it's too dangerous either that same turn or after untapping. Now, without Nephalia Drownyard, we don't have that option anymore in Standard. I'm thinking that when we hit a creature with an Azorius Charm and really don't want that card drawn next turn, we might be thinking on the untap that it might be a really good opportunity to draw 2 cards... and mill away that threat at the same time!, instead of wasting mana on Nephalia Drownyard merely to mill and nothing more. If there's nothing in particular to mill, then it can always just be cast like a Divination if we simply need to draw a few cards. I can't see any reason to run Divination over this in an Esper deck, but people aren't running Divination in Esper anyways. I don't know why you'd run Divination in Azorius Control but not in Esper Control. Anyways, yeah, pretty solid card, even in Standard in my opinion.
